required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Islet Cell Transplantation Alone and CD34+ Donor Bone Marrow Cell Infusion in Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus
clinical_study.official_title: Islet Cell Transplantation Alone and CD34+ Enriched Donor Bone Marrow Cell Infusion in Patients With Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus; Steroid Free Regimen

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

brief_summary.textblock:
SPECIFIC AIMS:
- To reverse hyperglycemia and insulin dependency in patients with Type 1 diabetes mellitus by islet cell transplantation.
- To induce a state of donor specific tolerance and eliminate the need for continuous immunosuppressive therapy by simultaneous transplantation of donor bone marrow cells with islets and utilization of the monoclonal antibody Campath-1H for induction of Immunosuppression.
- To assess long-term function of successful islet cell transplants in patients with Type 1 diabetes mellitus.
- To determine whether the natural history of the microvascular, macrovascular and neuropathic complications are altered following successful transplantation of islet

detailed_description.textblock: In our current protocol (IRB #2000/0024) the immunosuppressive regimen, comprised of induction with daclizumab and maintenance therapy with sirolimus and tacrolimus, has been combined with the infusion of CD34+ enriched donor bone marrow stem cells in an attempt to create a chimeric state and hence induce donor tolerance. This strategy was tested by evaluating graft survival following the removal of all immunosuppressive medication after one year.

clinical_study.why_stopped: We did not achieve a tolerogenic profile. Subjects withdrew from protocol and enrolled in other islet transplant trials.

primary_outcome.measure: The Achievement of Persistent Islet Function Following Cessation of Immunosuppression.
primary_outcome.time_frame: for the duration of islet graft function
primary_outcome.description: Immunosuppression was never discontinued. Patients elected to move to other trials to receive additional islet infusions. Since immunosuppression was never discontinued we were not able to evaluate the primary endpoint.

primary_outcome.measure: A Reduction or Absence of Rejection Episodes
primary_outcome.time_frame: for the duration of islet graft function
primary_outcome.description: Number of rejection episodes after transplantation. Immunosuppression was never discontinued. Patients elected to move to other trials to receive additional islet infusions. Since immunosuppression was never discontinued we were not able to evaluate the primary endpoint.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects With Basal C-peptide Greater Than 0.5 ng/ml
secondary_outcome.time_frame: for the duration of islet graft function
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects with basal C-peptide greater than 0.5 ng/ml prior to weaning of immunosuppression;

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects With Reduction of Severe Hypoglycemia and Improvement in Hypoglycemia Awareness
secondary_outcome.time_frame: for the duration of islet graft function
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects with reduction of episodes of severe hypoglycemia and the presence of awareness of hypoglycemia

arm_group.description: Administration of islets and infusion of CD34 enriched Bone Marrow cells in subjects with type 1 diabetes, impaired awareness of hypoglycemia and severe hypoglycemia.

intervention.description: Islet transplantation and CD34 Bone Marrow infusion in subjects with type 1 diabetes.

overall_official.affiliation: Diabetes Research Institute University of Miami

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
